revision.comment: Alter: issue, pages. Add: citeseerx, issue, pages, pmc, pmid. Removed parameters. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
'''Orphan genes''' (also called '''[[Open reading frame|ORF]]<nowiki/>ans''', especially in microbial literature)<ref name="fischer_1999">{{cite journal|last1=Fischer|first1=D.|last2=Eisenberg|first2=D.|title=Finding families for genomic ORFans|journal=Bioinformatics|date=1 September 1999|volume=15|issue=9|pages=759–762|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/15.9.759|pmid=10498776}}</ref><ref name="Tautz">{{cite journal |last1 = Tautz|first1 = D.|last2 = Domazet-Lošo|first2 = T.|year = 2011|title = The evolutionary origin of orphan genes|url = |journal = Nature Reviews Genetics|volume = 12|issue = 10|pages = 692–702|doi = 10.1038/nrg3053|pmid = 21878963}}</ref> are [[genes]] without detectable [[Homology (biology)|homologues]] in other lineages.<ref name="Tautz" /> Orphans are a subset of taxonomically-restricted genes (TRGs), which are unique to a specific taxonomic level (e.g. plant-specific).<ref name="Khalturin" /> In contrast to non-orphan TRGs, orphans are usually considered unique to a very narrow taxon, generally a species.
The classic model of evolution is based on duplication, rearrangement, and mutation of genes with the idea of common descent.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Evolution by Gene Duplication|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5SjqCAAAQBAJ|publisher = Springer Science & Business Media|date = 2013-12-11|isbn = 978-3-642-86659-3 |first = Susumu|last = Ohno}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = On the origin of new genes in Drosophila|url = http://genome.cshlp.org/content/18/9/1446|journal = Genome Research|date = 2008-09-01|pmc = 2527705|pmid = 18550802|pages = 1446–1455|volume = 18|issue = 9|doi = 10.1101/gr.076588.108|first = Qi|last = Zhou|first2 = Guojie|last2 = Zhang|first3 = Yue|last3 = Zhang|first4 = Shiyu|last4 = Xu|first5 = Ruoping|last5 = Zhao|first6 = Zubing|last6 = Zhan|first7 = Xin|last7 = Li|first8 = Yun|last8 = Ding|first9 = Shuang|last9 = Yang}}</ref> Orphan genes differ in that they are lineage-specific with no known history of shared duplication and rearrangement outside of their specific species or clade.<ref name="Toll-Riera">{{cite journal | last1 = Toll-Riera | first1 = M. | last2 = Bosch | first2 = N. | last3 = Bellora | first3 = N. | last4 = Castelo | first4 = R. | last5 = Armengol | first5 = L. | last6 = Estivill | first6 = X. | last7 = Alba | first7 = M. M. | year = 2009 | title = Origin of primate orphan genes: a comparative genomics approach | url = | journal = Molecular Biology and Evolution | volume = 26 | issue = 3| pages = 603–612 | doi=10.1093/molbev/msn281 | pmid=19064677}}</ref> Orphan genes may arise through a variety of mechanisms, such as horizontal gene transfer, duplication and rapid divergence, and de novo origination,<ref name="Tautz" /> and may act at different rates in insects, primates, and plants.<ref name="Wissler">{{cite journal | last1 = Wissler | first1 = L. | last2 = Gadau | first2 = J. | last3 = Simola | first3 = D. F. | last4 = Helmkampf | first4 = M. | last5 = Bornberg-Bauer | first5 = E. | year = 2013 | title = Mechanisms and Dynamics of Orphan Gene Emergence in Insect Genomes | url = | journal = Genome Biology and Evolution | volume = 5 | issue = 2| pages = 439–455 | doi=10.1093/gbe/evt009 | pmid=23348040 | pmc=3590893}}</ref> Despite their relatively recent origin, orphan genes may encode functionally important proteins.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = De Novo ORFs in Drosophila Are Important to Organismal Fitness and Evolved Rapidly from Previously Non-coding Sequences|journal = PLoS Genet|date = 2013-10-17|pmc = 3798262|pmid = 24146629|pages = e1003860|volume = 9|issue = 10|doi = 10.1371/journal.pgen.1003860|first = Josephine A.|last = Reinhardt|first2 = Betty M.|last2 = Wanjiru|first3 = Alicia T.|last3 = Brant|first4 = Perot|last4 = Saelao|first5 = David J.|last5 = Begun|first6 = Corbin D.|last6 = Jones}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = NCYM, a Cis-Antisense Gene of MYCN, Encodes a De Novo Evolved Protein That Inhibits GSK3β Resulting in the Stabilization of MYCN in Human Neuroblastomas|journal = PLoS Genet|date = 2014-01-02|pmc = 3879166|pmid = 24391509|pages = e1003996|volume = 10|issue = 1|doi = 10.1371/journal.pgen.1003996|first = Yusuke|last = Suenaga|first2 = S. M. Rafiqul|last2 = Islam|first3 = Jennifer|last3 = Alagu|first4 = Yoshiki|last4 = Kaneko|first5 = Mamoru|last5 = Kato|first6 = Yukichi|last6 = Tanaka|first7 = Hidetada|last7 = Kawana|first8 = Shamim|last8 = Hossain|first9 = Daisuke|last9 = Matsumoto}}</ref>
==History of orphan genes== Orphan genes were first discovered when the yeast genome-sequencing project began in 1996.<ref name="Tautz"/> Orphan genes accounted for an estimated 26% of the yeast genome, but it was believed that these genes could be classified with homologues when more genomes were sequenced.<ref name="Khalturin"/> At the time, gene duplication was considered the only serious model of gene evolution<ref name="Tautz" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Jacob|first=F.|date=1977-06-10|title=Evolution and tinkering|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/196/4295/1161|journal=Science|language=en|volume=196|issue=4295|pages=1161–1166|doi=10.1126/science.860134|pmid=860134|bibcode=1977Sci...196.1161J}}</ref> and there were few sequenced genomes for comparison, so a lack of detectable homologues was thought to be most likely due to a lack of sequencing data and not due to a true lack of homology.<ref name="Khalturin" /> However, orphan genes continued to persist as the quantity of sequenced genomes grew,<ref name="Khalturin" /><ref name="Wilson">{{cite journal | last1 = Wilson | first1 = G. A. | last2 = Bertrand | first2 = N. | last3 = Patel | first3 = Y. | last4 = Hughes | first4 = J. B. | last5 = Feil | first5 = E. J. | last6 = Field | first6 = D. | year = 2005 | title = Orphans as taxonomically restricted and ecologically important genes | url = | journal = Microbiology | volume = 151 | issue = 8| pages = 2499–2501 | doi=10.1099/mic.0.28146-0 | pmid=16079329}}</ref> eventually leading to the conclusion that orphan genes are ubiquitous to all genomes.<ref name="Tautz" /> Estimates of the percentage of genes which are orphans varies enormously between species and between studies; 10-30% is a commonly cited figure.<ref name="Khalturin">{{cite journal | last1 = Khalturin | first1 = K | last2 = Hemmrich | first2 = G | last3 = Fraune | first3 = S | last4 = Augustin | first4 = R | last5 = Bosch | first5 = TC | year = 2009 | title = More than just orphans: are taxonomically-restricted genes important in evolution? | url = | journal = Trends in Genetics | volume = 25 | issue = 9| pages = 404–413 | doi=10.1016/j.tig.2009.07.006 | pmid=19716618}}</ref>
The study of orphan genes emerged largely after the turn of the century. In 2003, a study of ''[[Caenorhabditis briggsae]]'' and related species compared over 2000 genes.<ref name="Khalturin"/> They proposed that these genes must be evolving too quickly to be detected and are consequently sites of very rapid evolution.<ref name="Khalturin"/> In 2005, Wilson examined 122 bacterial species to try to examine whether the large number of orphan genes in many species was legitimate.<ref name="Wilson"/> The study found that it was legitimate and played a role in bacterial adaptation. The definition of taxonomically-restricted genes was introduced into the literature to make orphan genes seem less "mysterious."<ref name="Wilson"/>
In 2008, a yeast protein of established functionality, BSC4, was found to have evolved de novo from non-coding sequences whose homology was still detectable in sister species.<ref name="Cai 2008">{{Cite journal|last=Cai|first=Jing|last2=Zhao|first2=Ruoping|last3=Jiang|first3=Huifeng|last4=Wang|first4=Wen|date=2008-05-01|title=De Novo Origination of a New Protein-Coding Gene in Saccharomyces cerevisiae|url=http://www.genetics.org/content/179/1/487|journal=Genetics|language=en|volume=179|issue=1|pages=487–496|doi=10.1534/genetics.107.084491|pmc=2390625|pmid=18493065}}</ref>
In 2009, an orphan gene was discovered to regulate an internal biological network: the orphan gene, QQS, from ''Arabidopsis thaliana'' modifies plant composition.<ref name="Foster, C. M. 2009">{{cite journal | last1 = Li | first1 = L. | last2 = Foster | first2 = C. M. | last3 = Gan | first3 = Q. | last4 = Nettleton | first4 = D. | last5 = James | first5 = M. G. | last6 = Myers | first6 = A. M. | last7 = Wurtele | first7 = E. S. | year = 2009 | title = Identification of the novel protein QQS as a component of the starch metabolic network in Arabidopsis leaves | url = | journal = The Plant Journal | volume = 58 | issue = 3| pages = 485–498 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-313X.2009.03793.x | pmid = 19154206 }}</ref> The QQS orphan protein interacts with a conserved transcription factor, these data explain the compositional changes (increased protein) that are induced when QQS is engineered into diverse species.<ref name=":3">{{cite journal | last1 = Li | first1 = L | last2 = Zheng | first2 = W | last3 = Zhu | first3 = Y | last4 = Ye | first4 = H | last5 = Tang | first5 = B | last6 = Arendsee | first6 = Z | last7 = Jones | first7 = D | last8 = Li | first8 = R | last9 = Ortiz | first9 = D | last10 = Zhao | first10 = X | last11 = Du | first11 = C | last12 = Nettleton | first12 = D | last13 = Scott | first13 = P | last14 = Salas-Fernandez | first14 = M | last15 = Yin | first15 = Y | last16 = Wurtele | first16 = ES | year = 2015 | title = The QQS orphan gene regulates carbon and nitrogen partitioning across species via NF-YC interactions | url = | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. | volume = 112| issue = 47| pages = 14734–14739| doi = 10.1073/pnas.1514670112 | pmid = 26554020 | bibcode = 2015PNAS..11214734L | pmc = 4664325 }}</ref> In 2011, a comprehensive genome-wide study of the extent and evolutionary origins of orphan genes in plants was conducted in the model plant ''Arabidopsis thaliana'' "<ref name="Donoghue">{{cite journal | last1 = Donoghue | first1 = M.T.A | last2 = Keshavaiah | first2 = C. | last3 = Swamidatta | first3 = S.H. | last4 = Spillane | first4 = C. | year = 2011 | title = Evolutionary origins of Brassicaceae specific genes in Arabidopsis thaliana | url = | journal = BMC Evolutionary Biology | volume = 11 | issue = 1| page = 47 | doi=10.1186/1471-2148-11-47| pmid = 21332978 | pmc = 3049755 }}</ref>
==How to identify orphan genes== Genes can be tentatively classified as orphans if no orthologous proteins can be found in nearby species.<ref name="Wissler"/>
One method used to estimate nucleotide or protein sequence similarity indicative of homology (i.e. similarity due to common origin) is the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST). BLAST allows query sequences to be rapidly searched against large sequence databases.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Altschul|first1=S.|title=Gapped BLAST and PSI-BLAST: a new generation of protein database search programs|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|date=1 September 1997|volume=25|issue=17|pages=3389–3402|doi=10.1093/nar/25.17.3389|pmid=9254694|pmc=146917}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NCBI BLAST homepage|url=http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi}}</ref> Simulations suggest that under certain conditions BLAST is suitable for detecting distant relatives of a gene.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Alba|first1=M|last2=Castresana|first2=J|title=On homology searches by protein BLAST and the characterization of the age of genes|journal=BMC Evol. Biol.|date=2007|volume=7|page=53|doi=10.1186/1471-2148-7-53 |pmid=17408474|pmc=1855329}}</ref> However, genes that are short and evolve rapidly can easily be missed by BLAST.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moyers|first1=B. A.|last2=Zhang|first2=J.|title=Phylostratigraphic Bias Creates Spurious Patterns of Genome Evolution|journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution|date=13 October 2014|volume=32|issue=1|pages=258–267|doi=10.1093/molbev/msu286|pmid=25312911|pmc=4271527}}</ref>
The systematic detection of homology to annotate orphan genes is called phylostratigraphy.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = A phylostratigraphy approach to uncover the genomic history of major adaptations in metazoan lineages|url = http://www.cell.com/article/S0168952507002995/abstract|journal = Trends in Genetics|date = 2007-01-11|pmid = 18029048|pages = 533–539|volume = 23|issue = 11|doi = 10.1016/j.tig.2007.08.014|first = Tomislav|last = Domazet-Lošo|first2 = Josip|last2 = Brajković|first3 = Diethard|last3 = Tautz}}</ref> Phylostratigraphy generates a phylogenetic tree in which the homology is calculated between all genes of a focal species and the genes of other species. The earliest common ancestor for a gene determines the age, or phylostratum, of the gene. The term "orphan" is sometimes used only for the youngest phylostratum containing only a single species, but when interpreted broadly as a taxonomically-restricted gene, it can refer to all but the oldest phylostratum, with the gene orphaned within a larger clade.
==Where do orphan genes come from?== Orphan genes arise from multiple sources, predominantly through de novo origination, duplication and rapid divergence, and horizontal gene transfer.<ref name="Tautz" />
=== De Novo Origination === Novel orphan genes continually arise de novo from non-coding sequences.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McLysaght|first1=Aoife|last2=Guerzoni|first2=Daniele|title=New genes from non-coding sequence: the role of de novo protein-coding genes in eukaryotic evolutionary innovation|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|date=31 August 2015|volume=370|issue=1678|pages=20140332|doi=10.1098/rstb.2014.0332|pmid=26323763|pmc=4571571}}</ref> These novel genes may be sufficiently beneficial to be swept to fixation by selection. Or, more likely, they will fade back into the non-genic background. This latter option is supported by research in Drosophila showing that young genes are more likely go extinct.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Palmieri|first1=Nicola|last2=Kosiol|first2=Carolin|last3=Schlötterer|first3=Christian|title=The life cycle of orphan genes|journal=eLife|date=19 February 2014|volume=3|pages=e01311|doi=10.7554/eLife.01311|pmid=24554240|pmc=3927632}}</ref>
De novo genes were once thought to be a near impossibility due to the complex and potentially fragile intricacies of creating and maintaining functional polypeptides,<ref name=":2" /> but research from the past 10 years or so has found multiple examples of de novo genes, some of which are associated with important biological processes, particularly testes function in animals. De novo genes were also found in fungi and plants.<ref name="Cai 2008" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zhao|first=Li|last2=Saelao|first2=Perot|last3=Jones|first3=Corbin D.|last4=Begun|first4=David J.|date=2014-02-14|title=Origin and Spread of de Novo Genes in Drosophila melanogaster Populations|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/343/6172/769|journal=Science|language=en|volume=343|issue=6172|pages=769–772|doi=10.1126/science.1248286|pmc=4391638|pmid=24457212|bibcode=2014Sci...343..769Z}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Levine|first=Mia T.|last2=Jones|first2=Corbin D.|last3=Kern|first3=Andrew D.|last4=Lindfors|first4=Heather A.|last5=Begun|first5=David J.|date=2006-06-27|title=Novel genes derived from noncoding DNA in Drosophila melanogaster are frequently X-linked and exhibit testis-biased expression|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/103/26/9935|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=103|issue=26|pages=9935–9939|doi=10.1073/pnas.0509809103|pmc=1502557|pmid=16777968|bibcode=2006PNAS..103.9935L}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zhou|first=Qi|last2=Zhang|first2=Guojie|last3=Zhang|first3=Yue|last4=Xu|first4=Shiyu|last5=Zhao|first5=Ruoping|last6=Zhan|first6=Zubing|last7=Li|first7=Xin|last8=Ding|first8=Yun|last9=Yang|first9=Shuang|date=2008-09-01|title=On the origin of new genes in Drosophila|url=http://genome.cshlp.org/content/18/9/1446|journal=Genome Research|language=en|volume=18|issue=9|pages=1446–1455|doi=10.1101/gr.076588.108|pmc=2527705|pmid=18550802}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heinen|first=Tobias J. A. J.|last2=Staubach|first2=Fabian|last3=Häming|first3=Daniela|last4=Tautz|first4=Diethard|date=2009-09-29|title=Emergence of a New Gene from an Intergenic Region|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982209014754|journal=Current Biology|volume=19|issue=18|pages=1527–1531|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2009.07.049|pmid=19733073}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chen|first=Sidi|last2=Zhang|first2=Yong E.|last3=Long|first3=Manyuan|date=2010-12-17|title=New Genes in Drosophila Quickly Become Essential|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/330/6011/1682|journal=Science|language=en|volume=330|issue=6011|pages=1682–1685|doi=10.1126/science.1196380|pmid=21164016|bibcode=2010Sci...330.1682C}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Reinhardt|first=Josephine A.|last2=Wanjiru|first2=Betty M.|last3=Brant|first3=Alicia T.|last4=Saelao|first4=Perot|last5=Begun|first5=David J.|last6=Jones|first6=Corbin D.|date=2013-10-17|title=De Novo ORFs in Drosophila Are Important to Organismal Fitness and Evolved Rapidly from Previously Non-coding Sequences|journal=PLOS Genet|volume=9|issue=10|pages=e1003860|doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1003860|pmc=3798262|pmid=24146629}}</ref><ref name="Silveira"> {{cite journal | vauthors=Silveira AB, Trontin C, Cortijo S, Barau J, Del-Bem LE, Loudet O, Colot V, Vincentz M | title=Extensive Natural Epigenetic Variation at a De Novo Originated Gene |journal=PLoS Genetics |volume=9 |issue=4 |pages=e1003437 |year=2013 |doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1003437 | pmid=23593031 | pmc=3623765 }}</ref>
For young orphan genes, it is sometimes possible to find homologous non-coding DNA sequences in sister taxa, which is generally accepted as strong evidence of de novo origin. However, the contribution of de novo origination to taxonomically-restricted genes of older origin, particularly in relation to the traditional gene duplication theory of gene evolution, remains contested.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Neme|first=Rafik|last2=Tautz|first2=Diethard|date=2014-03-17|title=Evolution: Dynamics of De Novo Gene Emergence|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982214001547|journal=Current Biology|volume=24|issue=6|pages=R238–R240|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2014.02.016|pmid=24650912}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moyers|first=Bryan A.|last2=Zhang|first2=Jianzhi|date=2016-01-11|title=Evaluating phylostratigraphic evidence for widespread de novo gene birth in genome evolution|url=http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2016/01/11/molbev.msw008|journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution|language=en|pages=1245–56|doi=10.1093/molbev/msw008|pmc=5010002| pmid=26758516|volume=33|issue=5}}</ref>
=== Duplication and Divergence === The duplication and divergence model for orphan genes involves a new gene being created from some duplication or divergence event and undergoing a period of rapid evolution where all detectable similarity to the originally duplicated gene is lost.<ref name="Tautz" /> While this explanation is consistent with current understandings of duplication mechanisms,<ref name="Tautz" /> the number of mutations needed to lose detectable similarity is large enough as to be a rare event,<ref name="Tautz" /><ref name=":0" /> and the evolutionary mechanism by which a gene duplicate could be sequestered and diverge so rapidly remains unclear.<ref name="Tautz" /><ref>{{Cite journal|title = The altered evolutionary trajectories of gene duplicates|journal = Trends in Genetics|date = 2004-11-01|pmid = 15475113|pages = 544–549|volume = 20|issue = 11|doi = 10.1016/j.tig.2004.09.001|first = Michael|last = Lynch|first2 = Vaishali|last2 = Katju|citeseerx = 10.1.1.335.7718}}</ref>
=== Horizontal Gene Transfer === Another explanation for how orphan genes arise is through a duplication mechanism called [[horizontal gene transfer]], where the original duplicated gene derives from a separate, unknown lineage.<ref name="Tautz" /> This explanation for the origin of orphan genes is especially relevant in bacteria and archaea, where horizontal gene transfer is common.
==Protein characteristics== Orphans genes tend to be very short (~6 times shorter than mature genes), and some are weakly expressed, tissue specific and simpler in codon usage and amino acid composition.<ref name="Zebulun W 2014">{{cite journal|last1=Arendsee|first1=Zebulun W.|last2=Li|first2=Ling|last3=Wurtele|first3=Eve Syrkin|title=Coming of age: orphan genes in plants|journal=Trends in Plant Science|date=November 2014|volume=19|issue=11|pages=698–708|doi=10.1016/j.tplants.2014.07.003|pmid=25151064}}</ref> Orphan genes tend to encode more [[intrinsically disordered proteins]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mukherjee|first1=S.|last2=Panda|first2=A.|last3=Ghosh|first3=T.C.|title=Elucidating evolutionary features and functional implications of orphan genes in ''Leishmania major''|journal=Infection, Genetics and Evolution|date=June 2015|doi=10.1016/j.meegid.2015.03.031|pmid=25843649|volume=32 |pages=330–337}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wilson|first1=Benjamin A.|last2=Foy|first2=Scott G.|last3=Neme |first3=Rafik |last4=Masel|first4=Joanna |author4link=Joanna Masel|title=Young genes are highly disordered as predicted by the preadaptation hypothesis of de novo gene birth |journal=Nature Ecology & Evolution|date=24 April 2017|volume=1|issue=6|pages=0146|doi=10.1038/s41559-017-0146|pmid=28642936|pmc=5476217}}</ref><ref name="willis_2018">{{cite journal |last1=Willis |first1=Sara |last2=Masel |first2=Joanna |title=Gene Birth Contributes to Structural Disorder Encoded by Overlapping Genes |journal=Genetics |date=19 July 2018 |volume=210 |issue=1 |pages=303–313 |doi=10.1534/genetics.118.301249 |pmid=30026186 |pmc=6116962 }}</ref>, although some structure has been found in one of the best characterized orphan genes<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bungard |first1=Dixie |last2=Copple |first2=Jacob S. |last3=Yan |first3=Jing |last4=Chhun |first4=Jimmy J. |last5=Kumirov |first5=Vlad K. |last6=Foy |first6=Scott G. |last7=Masel |first7=Joanna |last8=Wysocki |first8=Vicki H. |last9=Cordes |first9=Matthew H.J. |title=Foldability of a Natural De Novo Evolved Protein |journal=Structure |date=November 2017 |volume=25 |issue=11 |pages=1687–1696.e4 |doi=10.1016/j.str.2017.09.006|pmid=29033289 |pmc=5677532 }}</ref>. Of the tens of thousands of enzymes of primary or specialized metabolism that have been characterized to date, none are orphans, or even of restricted lineage; apparently, catalysis requires hundreds of millions of years of evolution.<ref name="Zebulun W 2014"/>
==Biological functions== While the prevalence of orphan genes has been established, the evolutionary role of orphans, and its resulting importance, is still being debated. One theory is that many orphans have no evolutionary role; genomes contain non-functional open reading frames (ORFs) that create spurious polypeptide products not maintained by selection, meaning that they are unlikely to be conserved between species and would likely be detected as orphan genes.<ref name="Khalturin" /> However, a variety of other studies have shown that at least some orphans are functionally important and may help explain the emergence of novel phenotypes.<ref name="Tautz" /><ref name="Khalturin" /><ref name="Wilson" /><ref name="Foster, C. M. 2009" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name="Donoghue" />
==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}
[[Category:Genomics]] [[Category:Evolution]]

revision.text: {{Coord|1|22|1.4|N|104|10|9.9|E|display=title}} {{Infobox factory | name = Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex | image = Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex.png | alt = | caption = | location_map = | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | location_map_alt = | built = | operated = | location = [[Pengerang]], [[Kota Tinggi District]], [[Johor]], [[Malaysia]] | industry = [[Petroleum industry|Oil and gas]] | products = | employees = | architect = | style = | buildings = | area = 80 km2 | volume = | address = | owner = | defunct = }} '''Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex''' ('''PIPC''') is a megaproject development in [[Pengerang]], [[Kota Tinggi District]], [[Johor]], [[Malaysia]]. It spans over an area of 80 km2 and will house [[oil refineries]], [[Petroleum naphtha|naphtha]] crackers, [[petrochemical]] plants, [[liquefied natural gas]] (LNG) terminals and a [[regasification]] plant upon completion.{{Cite web|url=http://jpdc.gov.my/pengerang-integrated-petroleum-complex-pipc|title=PIPC|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bharian.com.my/node/144708|title=PIPC mampu sumbang RM18.3b menjelang 2020|website=BH Online|access-date=2016-04-26}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.mida.gov.my/env3/uploads/Publications_pdf/MeetMalaysia_AsiaOilGasHub/MeetMalaysiaONG_2013|title=PIPC to become regional downstream oil storage and trading hub|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} ==Background== The site where it stands now was chosen because of its location along major shipping route between [[Middle East]] and [[China]]. The project was launched to increase [[Malaysia]]'s petrochemical output.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/metro/community/2016/04/18/pipc-a-boost-for-johor/|title=PIPC a boost for Johor - Community {{!}} The Star Online|last=Benjamin|first=Nelson|last2=Phaharoradzi|first2=Norbaiti|access-date=2016-04-26}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.mprc.gov.my/our-businesses/pengerang-integrated-petroleum-complex-pipc|title=Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex (PIPC) {{!}} MPRC|website=www.mprc.gov.my|access-date=2016-04-26}} ==Management== The Johor Petroleum Development Corporation Berhad (JPDC) was established to oversee the development of the project. JPDC was created as a subsidiary of Malaysia Petroleum Resources Corporation (MPRC){{Cite web|url=http://www.mprc.gov.my/our-businesses/pengerang-integrated-petroleum-complex-pipc|title=Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex (PIPC) {{!}} MPRC|website=www.mprc.gov.my|access-date=2016-04-26}}{{Cite web|url=http://etp.pemandu.gov.my/About_ETP-@-Overview_of_ETP.aspx|title=Overview of ETP|website=etp.pemandu.gov.my|access-date=2016-04-26}} ==Architecture== The components of PIPC was first initiated with the development of the 5 million cubic meters capacity of Pengerang Deepwater Terminal (PDT), a joint-venture between Dialog Group, Royal Vopak of the [[Netherlands]] and [[Johor]]. It serves as a centralized storage facility for trading, refining and [[petrochemical industry]]. The USD3 billion facility includes an independent terminal for trading, a dedicated industrial terminal within PIPC, and an LNG terminal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dialogasia.com/pengerangproject.htm|title=Dialog Group Berhad|website=www.dialogasia.com|access-date=2016-04-26}} The construction of a deepwater jetty facility enables the berthing of both ultra large crude carriers and very large crude carriers. PDT received its first shipment of oil in the first quarter of 2014. The other component of PIPC is the [[Petronas]] Pengerang Integrated Complex (PIC), Petronas' largest [[Downstream (petroleum industry)|downstream]] [[investment]] in a single location to date.{{Cite web|url=https://pic.petronas.com/Pages/default.aspx|title=Petronas' largest downstream investment in a single location|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} The development includes the USD16 billion Refinery and Petrochemical Integrated Development Project (RAPID). This also involves the USD11 billion associated facilities, which are air separation unit, raw water supply, cogeneration plant, regasification terminal, deepwater terminal and utilities. Upon its completion in 2019, PIC will have a refining capacity of 300,000 barrels per day with petrochemical plants yielding an estimated annual production capacity of 3.6 million tonnes of petrochemical products.{{Cite web|url=https://pic.petronas.com/About-PIC/Pages/The-Projects.aspx|title=PIC projects|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}{{cite news|last1=Chow|first1=Emily|last2=Ananthalakshmi|first2=A.|title=Aramco snub puts Malaysia's Petronas in tight spot over RAPID project|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-aramco-petronas-analysis-idUSKBN15B0YW|accessdate=27 January 2017|agency=Reuters|date=Jan 27, 2017}}http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/saudi-arabia-malaysia-sign-pacts-to-strengthen-bilateral-cooperation Its sheltered harbour with a natural water depth of 24 meters provides berthing conditions for [[Oil tanker|Ultra Large Crude Carriers]] (ULCCs) and [[Oil tanker|Very Large Crude Carriers]] (VLCCs).{{Cite web|url=http://jpdc.gov.my/pengerang-integrated-petroleum-complex-pipc|title=Johor Petroleum Development Corporation Berhad (JPDC) {{!}} Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex (PIPC)|website=Johor Petroleum Development Corporation Berhad (JPDC) {{!}} Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex (PIPC)|access-date=2016-04-26}} ==Transportation== The complex is accessible by road using the [[Senai–Desaru Expressway]] from [[Johor Bahru]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Johor]] [[Category:Buildings and structures under construction in Malaysia]] [[Category:Petroleum industry]]

revision.text:
A '''polymeric foam''' is a [[foam]], in liquid or solidified form, formed from [[polymer]]s.
Examples include: * [[Ethylene-vinyl acetate]] (EVA) foam, the copolymers of ethylene and vinyl acetate; also referred to as polyethylene-vinyl acetate (PEVA) * [[Low-density polyethylene]] (LDPE) foam, first grade of polyethylene (PE) * [[Nitrile rubber]] (NBR) foam, the copolymers of acrylonitrile (ACN) and butadiene * Polychloroprene foam or [[Neoprene]] * [[Polyimide foam]] * [[Polypropylene]] (PP) foam, including expanded polypropylene (EPP) and polypropylene paper (PPP) * [[Polystyrene]] (PS) foam, including expanded polystyrene (EPS), extruded polystyrene foam (XPS) and sometimes polystyrene paper (PSP) ** [[Styrofoam]], including extruded polystyrene foam (XPS) and sometimes expanded polystyrene (EPS) * [[Polyurethane]] (PU) foam ** [[LRPu]] low-resilience polyurethane ** [[Memory foam]] ** [[Sorbothane]] *Polyethylene foam, as used in [[PEF rod]] * [[Polyvinyl chloride]] (PVC) foam ** [[Closed-cell PVC foamboard]] * [[Silicone foam]] * [[Microcellular]] foam
== See also == *[[Ultralight material]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Foams]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2601:188:C100:AA6:6140:D119:CB1C:D913|2601:188:C100:AA6:6140:D119:CB1C:D913]] ([[User talk:2601:188:C100:AA6:6140:D119:CB1C:D913|talk]]) to last revision by Erik.Sauar. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption = World total primary energy supply of 155,505 [[Kilowatt hour#Watt hour multiples and billing units|TWh]] (or 13,371 [[tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]]) by fuels in 2012 (IEA, 2014) {{cite web |title = 2014 Key World Energy Statistics |date = 2014 |publisher = IEA |url = http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld2014.pdf |format = PDF |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6YIEFsQ6b?url=http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld2014.pdf |archivedate = 2015-05-05 |deadurl = no |df = }}{{rp|6,8}} | other = | label1 = Oil | value1 = 31.4 | color1 = #7C6250 | label2 = Coal/Peat/Shale | value2 = 29.0 | color2 = #313c42 | label3 = Natural Gas | value3 = 21.3 | color3 = #ef8e39 | label4 = Biofuels and waste | value4 = 10.0 | color4 = #ABFF57 | label5 = Nuclear | value5 = 4.8 | color5 = #de2821 | label6 = Hydro | value6 = 2.4 | color6 = #005CE6 | label7 = Others ([[Renewable energy|Renewables]]) | value7 = 1.1 | color7 = #00CC4B }} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption = World total primary energy supply of 155,505 [[Kilowatt hour#Watt hour multiples and billing units|TWh]] (or 13,371 [[tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]]) by region in 2012 (IEA, 2014) | other = | label1 = OECD | value1 = 39.2 | color1 = #66CCFF | label2 = Middle East | value2 = 5.1 | color2 = #FFFF57 | label3 = Non-OECD Europe /Eurasia | value3 = 8.9 | color3 = #009a39 | label4 = China | value4 = 21.8 | color4 = #de2821 | label5 = Asia (w/o China) | value5 = 12.3 | color5 = pink | label6 = Non-OECD Americas | value6 = 4.6 | color6 = #211873 | label7 = Africa | value7 = 5.5 | color7 = #ef8e39 | label8 = Bunkers | value8 = 2.6 | color8 = #313c42 }} {{Latest pie chart of world power by source}} '''Primary energy''' ('''PE''') is an [[energy]] form found in nature that has not been subjected to any [[energy engineering|human engineered]] conversion process. It is energy contained in raw [[fuel|fuels]], and other forms of energy received as input to a [[system]]. Primary energy can be [[non-renewable resource|non-renewable]] or [[renewable energy|renewable]]. Where primary energy is used to describe fossil fuels, the [[embodied energy]] of the fuel is available as thermal energy and around 70% is typically lost in conversion to electrical or mechanical energy. There is a similar 60-80% conversion loss when solar and wind energy is converted to electricity, but today's UN conventions on energy statistics counts the electricity made from wind and solar as the primary energy itself for these sources. One consequence of this counting method is that the contribution of wind and solar energy is under reported compared to fossil energy sources, and there is hence an international debate on how to count primary energy from wind and solar.{{cite web|last1=Sauar|first1=Erik|title=IEA underreports contribution solar and wind by a factor of three compared to fossil fuels|url=http://energypost.eu/iea-underreports-contribution-solar-wind-factor-three-compared-fossil-fuels/|website=energypost.eu|publisher=Energy Post|accessdate=22 April 2018}} '''Total primary energy supply''' ('''TPES''') is the sum of production and imports subtracting exports and storage changes.{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/sites/factbook-2013-en/06/01/01/index.html?contentType=&itemId=%2fcontent%2fchapter%2ffactbook-2013-41-en&mimeType=text%2fhtml&containerItemId=%2fcontent%2fserial%2f18147364&accessItemIds=|title=OECD Factbook 2013: Economic, Environmental and Social Statistics|year=2013|accessdate=12 April 2014}} The concept of primary energy is used in [[energy distance|energy statistics]] in the compilation of [[energy accounting|energy balances]], as well as in the field of [[energetics]]. In energetics, a primary energy source (PES) refers to the energy forms required by the energy sector to generate the supply of [[energy carrier|energy carriers]] used by human society.{{cite book |last1=Giampietro |first1=Mario |last2=Mayumi |first2=Kozo |title=The Biofuel Delusion: The Fallacy of Large Scale Agro-Biofuels Production |publisher=Earthscan, Taylor & Francis group |year=2009 |pages=336 |isbn=978-1-84407-681-9 }} '''Secondary energy''' is a carrier of energy, such as electricity. These are produced by conversion from a primary energy source. The use of primary energy as a measure ignores conversion efficiency. Thus forms of energy with poor conversion efficiency, particularly the thermal sources, coal, gas and nuclear are overstated, whereas energy sources such as hydroelectricity which are converted efficiently, while a small fraction of primary energy are significantly more important than their total raw energy supply may seem to imply.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} PE and TPES are better defined in the context of [[worldwide energy supply]]. ==Examples of sources== Primary energy sources should not be confused with the [[energy system]] components (or conversion processes) through which they are converted into energy carriers. {| class="wikitable" |- | colspan="3" valign="top" align="center" | '''Primary energy sources''' | rowspan="11" valign="center" align="center" | ''converted
by'' |''' Energy system component''' | rowspan="11" valign="center" align="center" | ''to'' |'''[[Energy carrier|Energy carriers]] (main)''' |- | rowspan="4" valign="top" | '''''Non-renewable
sources'''''At the scale of [[earth sciences]], all primary energy sources can be considered to be renewable. The non-renewable essence of resources (PES) is due to the scale of needs within human society. In certain situations, the use of resources by human society is performed at a much higher rate than the minimum rate at which it can be geophysically renewed. This is the rationale behind the differentiation between non-renewable primary energy sources (oil, coal, gas, uranium) and renewable primary energy sources (wind, solar, hydro). | rowspan="2" valign="top" | '''''[[Fossil fuel|Fossil
fuels]]''''' | [[Petroleum|Oil]] (or crude oil) | [[Oil refinery]] | [[Fuel oil]] |- | [[Coal]] or [[natural gas]] | [[Fossil fuel power station]] | [[Enthalpy]], [[mechanical work]] or [[electricity]] |- | rowspan="2" | '''''Mineral
fuels''''' | [[Natural uranium]]Some [[nuclear fuel]]s, such as [[plutonium]] or [[depleted uranium]], are also used in nuclear fission power plants. However, they cannot be considered to be primary energy sources as they cannot be found in nature in any quantity. Indeed, there must be a consumption of natural uranium (primary energy source) in order to make these other nuclear fuels available. | [[Nuclear power plant]] ([[thermonuclear fission]]) | Electricity |- |[[Thorium|Natural thorium]] |[[Thorium-based nuclear power|Thorium breeder reactor]] |Enthalpy or electricity |- | rowspan="6" colspan="2" valign="top" | '''''Renewable
sources''''' | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[Solar energy]] | [[Photovoltaic]] power plant (''see also [[Solar power]]'') | Electricity |- | [[Solar power tower]], [[solar furnace]] (''see also [[Solar thermal energy]]'') | Enthalpy |- | [[Wind energy]] | [[Wind farm]] (''see also [[Wind power]]'') | Mechanical work or electricity |- | Falling and flowing water, [[tidal energy]][http://www.weltycenter.org/energy2.htm "Energy and the Natural Environment"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024051438/http://www.weltycenter.org/energy2.htm |date=2008-10-24 }} by David A. Dobson, Ph.D., Welty Environmental Center Feature Article, accessed July 9, 2009 | [[hydroelectricity|Hydropower station]], [[wave farm]], [[tidal power station]] | Mechanical work or electricity |- | [[Biomass]] sources | Biomass power plant | Enthalpy or electricity |- | [[Geothermal energy]] | [[Geothermal electricity#Power station types|Geothermal power station]] | Enthalpy or electricity |} ==Usable energy== {{main|exergy}} [[File:Different energy forms (PES).png|thumb|Primary energy sources are transformed by the energy sector to generate energy carriers.]] Primary energy sources are transformed in [[energy conversion]] processes to more convenient forms of energy that can directly be used by society, such as [[electrical energy]], refined [[fuels]], or synthetic fuels such as [[hydrogen fuel]]. In the field of [[energetics]], these forms are called [[energy carrier]]s and correspond to the concept of "secondary energy" in energy statistics. ===Conversion to energy carriers (or secondary energy)=== Energy carriers are energy forms which have been transformed from primary energy sources. Electricity is one of the most common energy carriers, being transformed from various primary energy sources such as coal, oil, natural gas, and wind. Electricity is particularly useful since it has low entropy (is highly ordered) and so can be converted into other forms of energy very efficiently. [[District heating]] is another example of secondary energy.[https://www.energystar.gov/buildings/facility-owners-and-managers/existing-buildings/use-portfolio-manager/understand-metrics/difference U.S. EPA Energy STAR] Retrieved 2017-11-03 According to the [[laws of thermodynamics]], primary energy sources cannot be produced. They must be available to society to enable the production of energy carriers. [[Thermal efficiency|Conversion efficiency]] varies. For thermal energy, electricity and mechanical energy production is limited by [[Carnot's theorem]], and generates a lot of [[waste heat]]. Other non-thermal conversions can be more efficient. For example, while wind turbines do not capture all of the wind's energy, they have a high conversion efficiency and generate very little waste heat since wind energy is low entropy. In principle solar photovoltaic conversions could be very efficient, but current conversion can only be done well for narrow ranges of wavelength, whereas solar thermal is also subject to Carnot efficiency limits. Hydroelectric power is also very ordered, and converted very efficiently. The amount of usable energy is the [[exergy]] of a system. ===Site and source energy=== Site energy is the term used in North America for the amount of end-use energy of all forms consumed at a specified location. This can be a mix of primary energy (such as natural gas burned at the site) and secondary energy (such as electricity). Site energy is measured at the campus, building, or sub-building level and is the basis for energy charges on utility bills.{{cite web|title=Measuring energy: site energy vs. source energy in ENERGY STAR Portfolio Manager|url=http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/energy/efficiency/buildings/energy-benchmarking/update/getready/19453|publisher=[[Natural Resources Canada]]|accessdate=November 8, 2017}} Source energy, in contrast, is the term used in North America for the amount of primary energy consumed in order to provide a facility’s site energy. It is always greater than the site energy, as it includes all site energy and adds to it the energy lost during transmission, delivery, and conversion.{{Cite journal|last=Torcellini|first=Paul|last2=Pless|first2=Shanti|last3=Deru|first3=Michael|last4=Crawley|first4=Drury|date=June 2006|title=Zero energy buildings: a critical look at the definition|url=https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy06osti/39833.pdf|journal=ACEEE Summer Study|publisher=National Renewable Energy Laboratory/U.S. Department of Energy|volume=|pages=|via=}} While source or primary energy provides a more complete picture of energy consumption, it cannot be measured directly and must be calculated using conversion factors from site energy measurements. For electricity, a typical value is three units of source energy for one unit of site energy.{{cite web|title=Site Energy vs Source Energy|url=http://wbi.worldbank.org/energy/content/site-energy-vs-source-energy|publisher=The World Bank|accessdate=November 8, 2017}} However, this can vary considerably depending on factors such as the primary energy source or fuel type, the type of power plant, and the transmission infrastructure. One full set of conversion factors is available as technical reference from [[Energy Star|Energy STAR]].{{Cite web|url=https://portfoliomanager.energystar.gov/pdf/reference/Source%20Energy.pdf|title=Technical Reference: Source Energy|access-date=2017-11-09}} Either site or source energy can be an appropriate metric when comparing or analyzing energy use of different facilities. The U.S [[Energy Information Administration]], for example, uses primary (source) energy for its energy overviews{{Cite web|url=https://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/|title=Total Energy - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)|website=www.eia.gov|access-date=2017-11-09}} but site energy for its Commercial Building Energy Consumption Survey{{Cite web|url=https://www.eia.gov/consumption/commercial/terminology.php|title=Commercial Buildings Energy Consumption Survey (CBECS) - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)|website=www.eia.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}} and Residential Building Energy Consumption Survey.{{Cite web|url=https://www.eia.gov/consumption/residential/terminology.php|title=Residential Energy Consumption Survey (RECS) - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)|website=www.eia.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}} The US [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]]'s [[Energy Star|Energy STAR]] program recommends using source energy,{{Cite web|url=https://www.energystar.gov/buildings/facility-owners-and-managers/existing-buildings/use-portfolio-manager/understand-metrics/difference|title=The difference between source and site energy|website=www.energystar.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}} and the [[United States Department of Energy|US Department of Energy]] uses site energy in its definition of a [[Zero-energy building|zero net energy building]].{{Cite web|url=https://energy.gov/eere/buildings/articles/doe-releases-common-definition-zero-energy-buildings-campuses-and|title=DOE Releases Common Definition for Zero Energy Buildings, Campuses, and Communities|website=Energy.gov|access-date=2017-11-20}} == Outlook == [[File:TPES outlook.jpg|thumb|450px|center|Primary energy outlook. Projected from 2007 ([[Energy Information Administration|EIA]], 2010)]] == Energy accidents and fatalities == {{main|Energy accidents}} Energy accidents are accidents that occur in systems that provide energy or power. These can result in fatalities, as can the normal running of many systems, for example those deaths due to pollution. Globally, coal is responsible for 100,000 deaths per trillion kWh.[https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesconca/2012/06/10/energys-deathprint-a-price-always-paid/#2f9f079649d2 How Deadly Is Your Kilowatt? We Rank The Killer Energy Sources James Conca, June 10, 2012] == See also == {{portal|Energy}} * [[Energy and society]] * [[Energy development]] * [[Energy mix]] * [[Energy system]] * [[Future energy development]] ==Notes== == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * Kydes, Andy (Lead Author); Cutler J. Cleveland (Topic Editor). 2007. "Primary energy." In: Encyclopedia of Earth. Eds. Cutler J. Cleveland (Washington, D.C.: Environmental Information Coalition, National Council for Science and the Environment). [First published in the Encyclopedia of Earth June 1, 2006; Last revised August 14, 2007; Retrieved November 15, 2007. * {{cite book | last1 = Øvergaard | first1 = Sara | title = Definition of primary and secondary energy | date = September 2008 | publisher = [[Statistics Norway]] | location = Norway | url = http://unstats.un.org/unsd/envaccounting/londongroup/meeting13/LG13_12a.pdf | access-date = 2016-12-17 }} ==External links== * [http://www.eoearth.org/article/Primary_energy The Encyclopedia of Earth: Primary energy] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120127193231/http://ourenergyfutures.org/page-cid-7.html#Primary_Energy_Sources Our Energy Futures glossary: Primary Energy Sources] {{Footer energy}} [[Category:Energy]] [[Category:Energetics]] [[Category:Thermodynamics]]

revision.text:
{{about||the plant propagation technique known as softwood cutting|Cutting (plant)|the software company|SoftWood}} {{refimprove|date=October 2017}} [[file:Pinus sylvestris wood ray section 1 beentree.jpg|thumb|[[Scots Pine]], a typical and well-known softwood]]
'''Softwood''' is [[wood]] from [[gymnosperm]] trees such as [[conifer]]s. The term is opposed to [[hardwood]], which is the wood from [[angiosperm]] trees.
==Characteristics== Softwood is [[wood]] from [[gymnosperm]] trees such as [[pine]]s and [[spruce]]s. Softwoods are not necessarily softer than hardwoods.<ref name="Buckley">{{cite web|last1=Buckley|first1=Michael|title=A basic guide to softwoods and hardwoods|url=http://www.worldhardwoods.com/files/articles_basicguide.pdf|publisher=worldhardwoods.com|date=2005|format=PDF|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> In both groups there is an enormous variation in actual wood hardness, the range of density in hardwoods completely including that of softwoods. Some hardwoods (e.g. [[balsa]]) are softer than most softwoods, while the hardest hardwoods are much harder than any softwood. The woods of [[longleaf pine]], [[Douglas fir]], and [[Taxus|yew]] are much harder in the mechanical sense than several hardwoods.
Softwoods are generally most used by the construction industry and are also used to produce [[paper pulp]], and card products.<ref name="Ryan">{{cite web|last1=Ryan|first1=V.|title=REVISION CARDS - SOFTWOODS |url=http://www.technologystudent.com/joints/softwoods1.html |date=2012|publisher=technologystudent.com|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref>
Certain species of softwood are more resistant to insect attack from [[woodworm]], as certain insects prefer damp hardwood.
Softwood reproduces using [[pine cones|cones]] and occasionally [[nut (fruit)|nuts]].
==Known softwood trees and uses== * [[Douglas fir]] - [[Woodworking joints|joinery]], doors and heavy construction * [[Eastern white pine]] - furniture * [[European spruce]] - used throughout construction, panelling and cladding * [[Larch]] - used for cladding and boats * [[Lodgepole pine]] - roofing, flooring and in making chipboard and [[particle board]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Things we make from softwood trees|url=https://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/infd-52jc96|date=11 July 2017|publisher=forestry.gov.uk|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> * [[Parana pine]] - stair treads and joinery * [[Scots pine]] - construction industry, mostly for interior work * [[Sitka spruce]] - <ref>{{cite web|last1=Harding|first1=T.|title=British Softwoods:Properties and Uses |date=1988 |format=PDF |url=https://www.forestry.gov.uk/PDF/FCBU077.pdf/$FILE/FCBU077.pdf |publisher=forestry.gov.uk|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> * [[Southern yellow pine]] - joinery, flooring and [[Deck (building)|decking]] * [[Western hemlock]] - doors, joinery and furniture * [[Western red cedar]] (or red cedar) - furniture, decking, [[Cladding (construction)|cladding]], and [[roof shingles]] * [[Yew]] - interior and exterior furniture e.g. chairs, gate posts and wood turning
==Applications== Softwood is the source of about 80% of the world's production of [[timber]],<ref>United Nations {{google books|jSZxq4DQjIIC|Forest Products Annual Market Review 2007-2008|page=46}}</ref> with traditional centres of production being the [[Baltic region]] (including [[Scandinavia]] and [[Russia]]), [[North America]] and China. Softwood is typically used in construction as structural carcassing timber, as well as finishing timber.
==See also== *[[List of woods]] * [[United States – Canada softwood lumber dispute]] *[[Hardwood]] *[[Janka hardness test]] *[[Brinell scale]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Woodworking}} {{Authority control}} {{Portal bar|Trees|Forestry}}
